identified-content.object.title: War Next Door, The (TV Program)
Manhattan, AZ (TV Program)
identified-content.classifier: Top/Classifieds/Job Market/Job Categories/Media, Entertainment and Publishing

abstract.p: USA Network announces that it is canceling two original series on which it had pinned many hopes, The War Next Door and Manhattan, AZ (S)

block.p: When the USA Network lost the rights to show World Wrestling Federation matches this fall, it seemed a potentially stunning blow to its prime-time schedule. But the network said it would be able to stanch any potential ratings losses with its own original series.

When the USA Network lost the rights to show World Wrestling Federation matches this fall, it seemed a potentially stunning blow to its prime-time schedule. But the network said it would be able to stanch any potential ratings losses with its own original series.
Yesterday USA announced that it was canceling two original series on which it had pinned many hopes: ''The War Next Door'' and ''Manhattan, AZ.''

Those programs, both quirky, half-hour Sunday night comedies, had been shown for eight weeks. They drew poor ratings. Each was watched by an audience that averaged about 1.3 million people, executives said.
USA did not say what would ultimately replace the programs, but it is expected that for now movies would run on Sunday nights instead.
The timing of the cancellations was not ideal. The programs of the World Wrestling Federation formally moved to Viacom's TNN and MTV networks this week.

The wrestling federation won the right to switch cable networks early last summer after a long court battle. USA's Monday night W.W.F. wrestling program ''Raw Is War'' was often the No. 1 prime-time show on cable. With it, USA had been able to maintain its status as the top-rated basic-cable network in prime time.

Executives said they would soon announce plans for the network in the post-wrestling era. They also said yesterday that they had appointed a new head of programming, Jim Miller, previously a television writer and producer.

The network's senior vice president for original series, David Eick, is leaving for Studios USA, the USA Networks Inc. television production studio. Mr. Eick has signed a development deal with Studios USA.
